articles.headline: Led by Intel, Chip Makers Cut Outlook
articles.snippet: The forecasts suggest that the technology industry is about to enter a slump that will rival or possibly exceed the dot-com bust of 2001.
articles.abstract: The forecasts suggest that the technology industry is about to enter a slump that will rival or possibly exceed the dot-com bust of 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intel, the world’s largest producer of computer chips, warned on Wednesday that its sales could fall as much as 19 percent in the fourth quarter. Other major players in the chip industry, including Applied Materials and National Semiconductor, offered their own bleak outlooks.

articles.headline: The Golden Years, Tarnished
articles.snippet: With the economy and stocks in free fall, many retirees are now worried about having enough to carry them through.
articles.abstract: With the economy and stocks in free fall, many retirees are now worried about having enough to carry them through.
articles.lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla.  Since the stock market began to fall, friends have been coming to Barbara Goldsmith to talk about their depression, loss of appetite, insomnia and cravings for hot fudge sundaes.

articles.headline: What About Joe?
articles.snippet: The election campaign put Joe the Plumber and small business at the heart of the tax-policy debate. How’s the plumbing game for a pair of Brooklyn Joes?
articles.abstract: The election campaign put Joe the Plumber and small business at the heart of the tax-policy debate. How’s the plumbing game for a pair of Brooklyn Joes?
articles.lead_paragraph: JOE THE PLUMBER spent Election Day running vent lines for a new McDonald’s going up in Coney Island, chomping a breakfast of baby carrots as he hauled 10-foot lengths of four-inch No-Hub pipe from his van to the construction site around the corner.

articles.headline: The Cash-Strapped Turn to Barter
articles.snippet: Drawing on the reach of the Internet, many exchanges include participants from around the world.
articles.abstract: Drawing on the reach of the Internet, many exchanges include participants from around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAUGHT in the credit vise of 2008 that is threatening their livelihoods, small-business owners are turning in droves to an age-old source of commerce: the exchange of goods and services, or barter, to hold on to their precious cash.

articles.headline: Retailers Feel Pinch of Returns
articles.snippet: A steeply rising number of shoppers, driven by anxiety over jobs and savings, or an immediate need for cash, are marching back to stores with their purchases.
articles.abstract: A steeply rising number of shoppers, driven by anxiety over jobs and savings, or an immediate need for cash, are marching back to stores with their purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shopping at Nordstrom in Miami this month, Maria Kakouris indulged herself with a $200 pair of satin-and-snakeskin pumps. Then came a spasm of buyer’s remorse. “Those shoes  they are still in my car with the receipt,” said Ms. Kakouris, a real estate agent. “I’m thinking, where am I going to wear them?”

articles.headline: Heady Days Gone, City of London Struggles
articles.snippet: As Britain confronts the highest rate of unemployment in over a decade, the country’s financial center is suffering from a loss not just of jobs but of prestige, too.
articles.abstract: As Britain confronts the highest rate of unemployment in over a decade, the country’s financial center is suffering from a loss not just of jobs but of prestige, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: The City, London’s financial center, was both the engine and the symbol of London’s long boom. But as Britain confronts the highest rate of unemployment in over a decade, the City is suffering not just from the loss of jobs but of prestige, too.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Life Insurers Facing Cuts in Ratings
articles.snippet: Life insurance companies, hobbled by real estate investments and committed to paying some costly retirement contracts, face more cuts in their credit ratings before the year is up.
articles.abstract: Life insurance companies, hobbled by real estate investments and committed to paying some costly retirement contracts, face more cuts in their credit ratings before the year is up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Life insurance companies, hobbled by real estate investments and committed to paying some costly retirement contracts, face more cuts in their credit ratings before the year is up and have little choice but to seek capital in unforgiving markets.

articles.headline: G.M.’s Troubles Stir Question of Bankruptcy vs. a Bailout
articles.snippet: General Motors, with dire warnings, is seeking a bailout, but skeptics point to the benefits of bankruptcy, which can offer a new start.
articles.abstract: General Motors, with dire warnings, is seeking a bailout, but skeptics point to the benefits of bankruptcy, which can offer a new start.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Momentum is building in Washington for a rescue package for the auto industry to head off a possible bankruptcy filing by General Motors, which is rapidly running low on cash.

articles.headline: For a Washington Job, Be Prepared to Tell All
articles.snippet: Those seeking top posts in the Obama administration must fill out an extensive -- some say invasive -- application.
articles.abstract: Those seeking top posts in the Obama administration must fill out an extensive -- some say invasive -- application.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Want a top job in the Obama administration? Only pack rats need apply, preferably those not packing controversy.
